headline.main: War Mutes Critics of Costly Carrier Groups

lead_paragraph: In a sun-soaked homecoming as triumphant as anything seen here since the Persian Gulf war, nearly 10,000 people cheered, carried balloons and waved patriotic banners today as one of the first aircraft carriers to strike at Afghanistan, the Enterprise, returned to her home port. As far as the 5,500 sailors and airmen aboard the towering ship were concerned, they did more than drop the first American bombs on Taliban forces and Al Quaeda terrorist camps. They also muted critics of the nation's carrier force.
abstract: Fears that Navy's 12 aircraft carrier groups would be trimmed to 10 subside after carriers prove their worth during war in Afghanistan, where most of flying missions have been based on carriers because Pentagon could not quickly establish air bases ashore; carriers were being called too expensive and too vulnerable by many people earlier this year; Adm Vern Clark, chief of naval operations, is now reportedly considering proposals to expand fleet; photo (M)
